newsitem.title: USA: White House says U.S. launches new attack on Iraq.
newsitem.headline: White House says U.S. launches new attack on Iraq.

text.p: U.S. military forces carried out additional strikes on Tuesday against Iraqi air defence sites to protect the safety of U.S. aircraft and crews operating in the newly expanded no-fly zone in southern Iraq, the White House said.
"This operation is designed to eliminate sites not destroyed in Tuesday morning's initial cruise missile strike," spokesman Mike McCurry said in a statement.

The United States had fired 27 cruise missiles at military targets in Iraq on Tuesday morning, saying Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had re-emerged as a menace to world security and a threat to the flow of oil from the Gulf.

President Bill Clinton also announced that the no-fly zone -- a forbidden area for Iraqi combat aircraft -- would be expanded and refused to rule out additional missile attacks on air defense sites in southern Iraq.
In response, Saddam ordered his pilots to shoot down airmen who tried to enforce it the no-fly zone.
McCurry gave no details of the second strike but said the Pentagon would provide specifics early on Wednesday.
